doc.after: Some 44,000Â Native Americans served in the United States military during World WarÂ II: at the time, one-third of all able-bodied Indian men from 18 to 50 years of age.[99] Described as the first large-scale exodus of indigenous peoples from the reservations since the removals of the 19th century, the men's service with the U.S. military in the international conflict was a turning point in Native American history. The overwhelming majority of Native Americans welcomed the opportunity to serve; they had a voluntary enlistment rate that was 40% higher than those drafted.[100]
